,The patient is a 49-year-old man with a history of severe COPD, dilated cardiomyopathy (dCHF), coronary artery disease (CAD), and noncompliance, presenting with persistent dyspnea/hypoxia after leaving against medical advice (AMA) from OSH. He was found to have persistent renal failure as well.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 119/62 to 136/71 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 90% on nasal cannula.

The patient has coarse bilateral breath sounds with diffuse wheezes, regular heart rhythm with normal S1 and S2, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops, soft abdomen with mild diffuse tympanicity but no organomegaly or ascites, well-perfused extremities, and intention tremor bilaterally.
The patient's allergies include penicillins, unknown reactions to terbutaline, epinephrine, glucocorticoids, and iodine. He also has a history of confusion or delirium with prednisone use.
The patient is refusing labs, all medications, and will not provide information about his home medications or primary care physician contact details.
